questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with complaints of recurrent lesions on lips as shown in the image below, which is associated with fever. What is the characteristic feature seen in Tzanck smear? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multinucleated giant cells

 

The patient presents with recurrent vesicular lesions on the lips associated with fever, which is characteristic of Herpes labialis caused by the Herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1). This condition is often triggered by fever and is hence also called a "fever blister" or "cold sores."

 

Another condition with recurrent lesions at the same site, typically triggered by a particular medication each time the patient is exposed to it is “Fixed Drug Eruption”. But here the initial appearance of vesicles on the lips is noted. These vesicles are prone to rupture. Once ruptured, the vesicles transform into erosions and ulcers with polycyclic margins, characteristic of herpes labialis. A history of fever is important as it often triggers these outbreaks.

 

On a Tzanck smear, the characteristic finding for Herpes labialis is the presence of multinucleated giant cells and acantholytic cells. These multinucleate giant cells are formed by the fusion of infected cells, leading to the appearance of multiple nuclei within a single cell. The Tzanck smear is specifically used in dermatology to diagnose viral infections, particularly Herpes simplex and Varicella-zoster.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Henderson Patterson bodies: These are eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies seen in Molluscum contagiosum, a viral infection caused by a poxvirus. These are not associated with Herpes labialis and are not found on a Tzanck smear for this condition.

 

 

Option C. Acanthocytes: These are spiny red blood cells that are typically seen in liver diseases such as cirrhosis and in certain neurological disorders. They are not related to the findings in a Tzanck smear or Herpes labialis. Although "acantholytic cells" can also be seen in Herpes labialis, these are different from acanthocytes.

 

 

Option D. Owl eye appearance: This term describes the characteristic appearance of cells infected by Cytomegalovirus (CMV), where the nucleus shows a large inclusion giving it an "owl eye" look. This is not a feature of Herpes labialis and would not be seen on a Tzanck smear for this condition.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear is the characteristic diagnostic feature for Herpes labialis (HSV-1).

questions.text: A patient from a military background presented with rash, fever, and altered sensorium. There is also a deficiency of the membrane attacking complex. The likely cause can be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitidis

 

Neisseria meningitidis is a bacterium that commonly causes meningococcal infections, which can lead to serious conditions such as meningococcemia and meningitis. Patients with a deficiency in the membrane attack complex (MAC) of the complement system, specifically components C5 to C9, are at an increased risk of Neisserial infections. The MAC plays a crucial role in defending against Neisseria species by forming pores in the bacterial cell membrane, leading to cell lysis. Without this complex, individuals are susceptible to recurrent or disseminated Neisserial infections, which manifest with symptoms like rash, fever, and altered sensorium, as seen in this patient. The clinical presentation of rash, fever, and altered sensorium strongly suggests meningococcemia, a severe form of infection caused by Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is a type of herpesvirus that can cause a variety of symptoms, primarily in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not typically present with rash, fever, and altered sensorium linked to MAC deficiency.

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: This bacterium is associated with pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and other infections, particularly in hospital settings. It does not have a direct correlation with MAC deficiency and does not typically present with disseminated infections characterized by rash, fever, and altered sensorium.

 

Option D. Hemophilus influenzae: While Hemophilus influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections and meningitis, it is not specifically associated with MAC deficiency and does not fit the profile of disseminated Neisserial infections seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with deficiencies in the membrane attack complex (C5-C9) of the complement system are particularly susceptible to infections caused by Neisseria species, such as Neisseria meningitidis, which can lead to severe conditions like meningococcemia.

questions.text: A newborn presents with the condition shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bladder exstrophy

 

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital anomaly where the bladder is exposed outside the body. It presents as a defect in the lower abdominal wall, with the bladder mucosa visible. Characteristic features include a bifid scrotum, abnormal genitalia (bifid penis or clitoris), and exposure of the bladder trigone. The condition is often associated with other malformations, such as a wide pubic symphysis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Umbilical hernia: This condition involves protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect at the umbilicus but remains covered by skin. It does not expose the bladder.

 

Option B. Gastroschisis: This defect occurs lateral to the umbilicus, commonly on the right, with the intestines protruding outside the abdomen without a protective membrane. The defect does not involve the bladder.

 

Option D. Omphalocele: This condition is characterized by herniation of abdominal organs into the base of the umbilical cord, covered by a thin membrane. Unlike bladder exstrophy, the organs are covered, and the defect involves the umbilical ring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bladder exstrophy is a congenital condition where the bladder is exposed outside the abdomen, often accompanied by genital and pelvic abnormalities.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the clinic with complaints of oral ulcers and a burning sensation in the mouth. A picture of the patient's oral cavity is provided, which reveals several white patches on the tongue and inner cheek. Based on this presentation, what is the likely diagnosis for this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leukoplakia

 

  • Leukoplakia is characterized by the presence of white patches on the oral mucosa, which cannot be scraped off.
  • The patches may vary in appearance, from smooth to rough or nodular.
  • Common risk factors include tobacco use (both smoking and smokeless forms) and chronic alcohol consumption.
  • While it's a benign lesion, there is a risk of malignant transformation, which is why regular monitoring and biopsy of suspicious areas are vital.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythroplakia: Erythroplakia is less common than leukoplakia but has a higher potential for being either cancerous at the time of diagnosis or becoming malignant later. It appears as red patches or plaques and is often more concerning due to its higher risk of malignancy.

 

Option C. Submucosal fibrosis: Oral submucous fibrosis is a chronic, progressive scarring disease, mostly linked to areca nut (betel nut) chewing. It's particularly prevalent in the Indian subcontinent. It's characterized by stiffness of the oral mucosa leading to trismus (difficulty in opening the mouth), burning sensation on eating spicy food, and oral ulcers. Over time, the condition can progress, making it hard for the patient to open their mouth. This condition also has a risk of malignant transformation, and like leukoplakia, requires regular monitoring.

 

Option D. Malakoplakia: Malakoplakia is a rare inflammatory condition that can affect various organs, including the bladder, kidneys, and even the gastrointestinal tract. In the context of the oral cavity, it's extremely rare. It presents as soft yellow plaques. Histologically, it's characterized by the presence of unique cells called "Michaelis-Gutmann bodies".

 

  • Given the presentation described - white patches on the tongue and inner cheek of a chronic alcohol abuser - the diagnosis of leukoplakia (option A) is the most probable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leukoplakia is an oral mucosal lesion characterized by white patches that cannot be scraped off and is commonly associated with tobacco and alcohol use.
  • It has the potential for malignant transformation, necessitating regular monitoring and biopsy of suspicious areas.

choices.text: Interstitial cystitis
Polypoid cystitis

questions.text: A patient underwent cystoscopy, which showed multiple yellow-white plaques in the trigone of the bladder. The histopathology image is given below. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malakoplakia

 

The cystoscopy findings of multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone and histopathology image showing Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are consistent with malakoplakia.

 

  • Malakoplakia is a rare condition of unknown etiology primarily affecting the urinary bladder. It is likely associated with chronic inflammation and defective phagocytosis by macrophages. It is more commonly observed in immunocompromised patients and transplant recipients.
  • On cystoscopy, malakoplakia appears as multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone. The lesions are soft, flat, and slightly raised, with sizes ranging from 0.5 to 5 cm.
  • Histopathologically, malakoplakia shows massive accumulation of foamy macrophages, multinucleate giant cells, and lymphocytes.
  • Foamy macrophages contain granular cytoplasm that is PAS-positive.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies, characterized by cytoplasmic laminated concretions of calcium phosphate, are seen within macrophages.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies represent lysosomes filled with partially digested debris of bacteria, resulting from defective phagocytosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial cystitis: Interstitial cystitis is a chronic condition causing bladder pain and frequent, urgent urination. It does not present with yellow-white plaques or Michaelis-Gutmann bodies.

 

Option C. Polypoid cystitis: Polypoid cystitis presents with polypoid or papillary projections in the bladder, often due to chronic irritation, such as long-term catheter use. It does not show the specific histopathological features of malakoplakia.

 

Option D. Acute cystitis: Acute cystitis is an infection of the bladder characterized by symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency of urination. The cystoscopy findings would typically show an inflamed, red mucosa, not yellow-white plaques.

 

Educational objective:

 

Malakoplakia is characterized by multiple yellow-white plaques in the bladder trigone, as seen on cystoscopy, and histopathological findings of foamy macrophages with PAS-positive cytoplasm and Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. This condition is associated with chronic inflammation and defective phagocytosis, commonly affecting immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: A patient has an urge to urinate but he is not able to do. He has history of a fall astride injury. On examination blood is seen at meatus. Which of the following injury is most common? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bulbar urethra rupture

 

A patient with a fall astride injury, presenting with an inability to urinate and blood at the urethral meatus, strongly suggests a bulbar urethral rupture. The bulbar urethra is the most commonly injured part of the urethra in straddle injuries, which occur due to forceful compression against the pubic symphysis (e.g., falling onto a hard object like a bicycle crossbar or a beam).

 

  • The bulbar urethra is located within the superficial perineal pouch, and when it ruptures, urine and blood can accumulate in the superficial perineal space, leading to perineal swelling and hematoma.
  • Blood at the meatus is a classical sign of anterior urethral injury, which is often associated with bulbar urethral trauma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Membranous urethra rupture: Incorrect

 

  • The membranous urethra is commonly injured in pelvic fractures (e.g., motor vehicle accidents), not in straddle injuries. It is located in the deep perineal pouch, and its rupture leads to urine accumulation in the deep perineal space and retropubic space.
  • Patients with membranous urethral injuries often present with high-riding prostate on rectal examination, which is absent in this case.

 

Option C. Extraperitoneal urethra rupture: Incorrect

 

  • Extraperitoneal urethral rupture usually occurs with pelvic fractures, affecting the posterior urethra (prostatic or membranous urethra).
  • It leads to urine extravasation around the bladder, visible as fluid collection in the retropubic space on imaging.

 

Option D. Intraperitoneal urethra rupture: Incorrect

 

  • Intraperitoneal rupture typically refers to bladder rupture, not urethral injury.
  • It occurs due to a direct blow to a full bladder, leading to urine leakage into the peritoneal cavity, which presents with peritonitis symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bulbar urethral rupture is the most common site of urethral injury in straddle injuries, presenting with blood at the urethral meatus, perineal hematoma, and urinary retention.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with easy fatiguability. The mother also complains that the child has increased hunger between meals, which is relieved after food. Liver examination revealed no glycogen. What enzyme is most likely deficient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycogen synthase

 

Glycogen synthase: This is the correct answer. Glycogen synthase is responsible for synthesizing glycogen from glucose. A deficiency in glycogen synthase would result in the inability to produce glycogen, which aligns with the liver examination findings of no glycogen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (McArdle’s disease or glycogen storage disease type V) primarily affects skeletal muscle glycogen metabolism. Symptoms include muscle weakness, cramps, and exercise intolerance.

 

Option C. Debranching enzyme deficiency (Cori's disease or glycogen storage disease type III) presents with hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, and growth retardation. The liver would still contain glycogen, although with an abnormal structure.

 

Option D. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency (von Gierke's disease or glycogen storage disease type I) is characterized by severe fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, hepatomegaly, Renomegaly. In this case, glycogen is present in the liver but cannot be broken down efficiently into glucose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glycogen synthase is a key enzyme involved in glycogenesis, the process of synthesizing glycogen, which serves as a storage form of glucose in the liver and muscles. Glycogen synthase catalyzes the addition of glucose molecules to the growing glycogen chain by creating alpha-1,4-glycosidic linkages between glucose units. This enzyme is regulated by various factors, including insulin, which promotes glycogen synthesis by activating glycogen synthase.

 

Mutations or dysregulation of glycogen synthase can lead to Glycogen Storage Disease 0 (GSD 0), a disorder resulting from mutations in the GYS2 gene encoding liver glycogen synthase. C/f include fasting hypoglycemia, hunger between meals, hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), and other metabolic abnormalities due to impaired glycogen synthesis.

questions.text: A patient experienced difficulty maintaining balance immediately after a roller coaster ride. Which of the following is most likely involved in the normal balance mechanism?(FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vestibulospinal tract

 

The vestibulospinal tract is responsible for maintaining balance and posture. It originates from the vestibular nuclei in the brainstem and plays a crucial role in equilibrium. When balance is disrupted, as in this case after a roller coaster ride, the vestibulospinal tract helps in regaining postural stability by:

 

  • Receiving input from the vestibular apparatus
  • Coordinating with antigravity muscles
  • Making postural adjustments to maintain balance
  • Working with the vestibular system for maintaining equilibrium

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rubrospinal tract: (Incorrect)

 

  • This tract is part of the extrapyramidal system
  • It helps in flexor muscle control
  • Not primarily involved in balance maintenance
  • Works with rubrospinal tract and reticulospinal tract for gross motor movements

 

Option C. Corticospinal tract: (Incorrect)

 

  • This is the main motor pathway for voluntary movements
  • Originates from the motor cortex
  • Not directly involved in balance maintenance
  • Controls fine, skilled movements

 

Option D. Reticulospinal tract: (Incorrect)

 

  • Part of the extrapyramidal system
  • Involved in autonomic functions and crude movements
  • While it contributes to posture, it's not the primary tract for balance
  • Originates from reticular formation

 

Educational Objective:

 

The vestibulospinal tract is primarily responsible for maintaining balance and posture by integrating vestibular system input and facilitating extensor muscle activity to stabilize the body during motion and positional changes. It plays a crucial role in postural adjustments following vestibular disturbances, such as those experienced after rapid or erratic motion, like a roller coaster ride.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presented with abdominal pain. His amylase and lipase levels were elevated. Which of the following will be seen? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Enzymatic fat necrosis

 

The patient, a chronic alcoholic, presents with abdominal pain and elevated levels of amylase and lipase, which are indicative of pancreatitis. In cases of both acute and chronic pancreatitis, the typical pathological finding is enzymatic fat necrosis. This occurs when pancreatic enzymes, particularly lipase, escape into the surrounding tissues, leading to fat digestion and necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coagulative necrosis: This type of necrosis is typically associated with ischemic injury, such as myocardial infarction, and is characterized by the preservation of cellular outlines.

 

Option C. Caseous necrosis: This type of necrosis is characteristic of tuberculosis infections and some fungal infections. It presents with a cheese-like appearance and is not associated with pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Fibrinoid necrosis:  This type of necrosis is usually seen in immune reactions involving blood vessels, such as in vasculitis or severe hypertension, where immune complexes and fibrin are deposited in vessel walls.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pancreatitis, especially in chronic alcoholics, the characteristic pathological finding is enzymatic fat necrosis, resulting from the action of pancreatic enzymes on the surrounding fatty tissues.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency department with head trauma due to a road traffic accident. In the hospital, the patient developed seizures. An emergency CT scan revealed widespread cerebral edema. Which of the following is the diuretic of choice for cerebral edema in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mannitol

 

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic and is the drug of choice for treating cerebral edema, particularly in cases of traumatic brain injury, like the one described. Mannitol works by creating an osmotic gradient that draws fluid out of the brain parenchyma and into the intravascular space, thereby reducing intracranial pressure and alleviating cerebral edema. This makes it the first-line treatment in emergency situations involving cerebral edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that works by antagonizing aldosterone in the distal nephron. It is not effective in managing cerebral edema and is primarily used in conditions like heart failure and certain cases of hyperaldosteronism.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that is effective in treating peripheral and pulmonary edema by inhibiting the reabsorption of sodium and chloride in the loop of Henle. While it is a potent diuretic, it is not the first choice for cerebral edema because it does not effectively lower intracranial pressure as mannitol does.

 

Option D. Hydrochlorothiazide: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used mainly for hypertension and mild fluid retention. It is not used in the treatment of cerebral edema and would not be effective in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mannitol is the diuretic of choice for treating cerebral edema, particularly in emergency settings following traumatic brain injury, due to its ability to reduce intracranial pressure by drawing fluid out of the brain tissue.

choices.text: pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3-5 mEq/L
pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L
pH - 7.54, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2-34 mm Hg
pH- 7.4, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 40 mm Hg

questions.text: A middle-aged man with chronic renal failure on dialysis presents with sudden collapse to the casualty with labored breathing. ECG shows tall tented T waves. What is the most likely acid-base imbalance that can be seen in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3-5 mEq/L

 

The patient with chronic renal failure presenting with sudden collapse and labored breathing is indicative of a severe acid-base disturbance, most likely metabolic acidosis. The tall tented T waves on the ECG suggest hyperkalemia, a common finding in metabolic acidosis and renal failure.

 

Patients with chronic renal failure often have a high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the accumulation of uremic toxins. The lab values in pH - 7.14, pCO2 - 20 mm Hg, HCO3 - 5 mEq/L indicate a severe metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation. The low bicarbonate level confirms metabolic acidosis, and the low pCO2 indicates compensatory hyperventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. pH- 7.14, pCO2- 20 mm Hg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L: This combination is inconsistent with metabolic acidosis because the bicarbonate level is high, which would not be seen in metabolic acidosis.

 

Option C. pH - 7.54, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2-34 mm Hg: This represents metabolic alkalosis or compensated respiratory acidosis, neither of which are consistent with the clinical picture of chronic renal failure and hyperkalemia.

 

Option D. pH- 7.4, HCO3 - 27 mEq/L, pCO2- 40 mm Hg: This reflects a normal pH, which would not be seen in the acute setting described, especially with the presence of severe symptoms and hyperkalemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with chronic renal failure are at risk for high anion gap metabolic acidosis. In cases of sudden collapse with labored breathing and ECG changes like tall tented T waves, metabolic acidosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Which muscle is affected if the patient is unable to make an "OK" sign? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flexor pollicis longus

 

The inability to make an "OK" sign is typically caused by a lesion of the anterior interosseous nerve, a branch of the median nerve. This nerve innervates three muscles, including the flexor pollicis longus (FPL), which is responsible for flexing the thumb. When the FPL is affected, the patient cannot flex the distal phalanx of the thumb, resulting in an inability to form the "OK" sign with their hand. The term "Kiloh-Nevin sign" is used to describe this clinical finding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor pollicis brevis: This muscle abducts the thumb and is innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve. It does not contribute to flexing the thumb for the "OK" sign.

 

Option C. Lumbricals: These muscles flex the metacarpophalangeal joints and extend the interphalangeal joints. They are not involved in making the "OK" sign.

 

Option D. Opponens pollicis: This muscle is involved in opposition of the thumb, allowing the thumb to touch the fingers, but it does not contribute directly to the flexion of the thumb required for the "OK" sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flexor pollicis longus is essential for making the "OK" sign, and its impairment is a key clinical feature of anterior interosseous nerve damage.

questions.text: A patient presents with a history of trauma and the following radiological image. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blow Out Fracture

 

Explanation: 

 

A blow out fracture is characterized by:

 

  • Tear drop sign on radiological imaging
  • Fracture of the orbital floor
  • Herniation of contents into the maxillary sinus
  • Typically results from blunt trauma

 

Clinical findings include:

 

  • Restriction of upward gaze
  • Diplopia in up gaze
  • Decreased sensation in infraorbital cheek area
  • Potential enophthalmos (sunken eye)

 

Diagnostic confirmation is done through:

 

  • Forced duction test (FDT) to differentiate restrictive from paralytic pathology

 

Other Options: 


Option A. Orbital Lateral Wall Fracture : Incorrect. Does not match the characteristic tear drop sign of floor fracture.

 

Option B. Orbital Medial Wall Fracture : Incorrect. Location does not correspond to the radiological findings.

 

Option D. Orbital Cellulitis : Incorrect. This is an inflammatory condition, not a traumatic fracture.

 

Educational Objective: 


Recognize the radiological tear drop sign as a key indicator of an orbital floor blow out fracture following blunt trauma.

questions.text: A child presents with intellectual disability, short stature, hypotonia, obesity, small hands and feet, and hypogonadism. He has been diagnosed with Prader-Willi syndrome. Which of the following chromosomes is affected in this patient? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chromosome 15

 

Prader-Willi syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by abnormalities on chromosome 15.

 

This occurs due to one of three mechanisms:

 

  • Deletion of the paternal chromosome 15 (most common, about 70% of cases)
  • Maternal uniparental disomy (both copies of chromosome 15 come from the mother)
  • Imprinting defect.

 

Prader willi syndrome

 

Etiology

 

  • Deletion of paternal chromosome (MC cause)
  • Uniparental Disomy (maternal chromosome)
  • ↓↓ SNORP (Small nucleolar RNA Proteins)

 

Clinical features

 

  • Mental Retardation
  • Obesity
  • Hypotonia
  • Hypogonadism

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chromosome 11: Incorrect. Chromosome 11 abnormalities are associated with other conditions like Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome and Wilms tumor, not Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Option B. Chromosome 12: Incorrect. Chromosome 12 is not associated with Prader-Willi syndrome. Abnormalities of this chromosome may be linked to other conditions.

 

Option D. Chromosome 17: Incorrect. Chromosome 17 is associated with conditions like Miller-Dieker syndrome and Smith-Magenis syndrome, not Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by abnormalities on chromosome 15, specifically the absence of paternally expressed genes in the 15q11-q13 region.

questions.text: A patient with coronary artery disease presents to you with chest pain and palpitations. The ECG is shown below. Which of the following can be used in the management? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Intravenous amiodarone

 

The ECG indicates a monomorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT), which is a type of fast heart rhythm originating from one of the ventricles. The appropriate management of stable monomorphic VT involves the use of intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Monomorphic Ventricular Tachycardia: This condition is characterized by a consistent QRS complex morphology on the ECG, suggesting a single focus of origin within the ventricles.
  • Stable vs. Unstable VT: For stable VT (where the patient does not exhibit hemodynamic instability such as hypotension, altered mental status, or severe chest pain), the initial treatment involves intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs.
  • Intravenous Amiodarone: According to the Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) guidelines, intravenous amiodarone is a recommended first-line therapy for stable monomorphic VT. Other options include procainamide and sotalol, but amiodarone is widely used due to its efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral metoprolol: Oral metoprolol is not typically used in the acute management of monomorphic VT. Beta-blockers like metoprolol are more suitable for rate control in atrial arrhythmias or for long-term management of heart rate.

 

Option B. Oral amiodarone: While amiodarone is appropriate for treating VT, oral administration is not suitable for acute management due to the need for rapid onset of action, which intravenous administration provides.

 

Option D. Intravenous metoprolol: Although intravenous beta-blockers can be used in certain arrhythmias, they are not the first-line treatment for monomorphic VT. Intravenous amiodarone or other antiarrhythmics are preferred for their effectiveness in stabilizing the ventricular rhythm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable monomorphic ventricular tachycardia, intravenous antiarrhythmic drugs such as amiodarone, procainamide, or sotalol are recommended as first-line treatments according to ACLS guidelines.

choices.text: Na- Ca transporter

questions.text: A child with loose stools for one day presented to your OPD. On examination, signs of dehydration were present and the child was given ORS. It facilitates glucose absorption through which of the following receptors? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. SGLT1

 

Explanation

 

ORS contains Na+ and glucose which facilitates glucose absorption through SGLT 1 (Sodium-dependent glucose co-transporter - 1).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. SGLT2: Incorrect. SGLT2 is another sodium-glucose linked transporter but is primarily found in the kidneys where it reabsorbs glucose from the filtrate back into the bloodstream. It is not involved in intestinal glucose absorption and thus not relevant to ORS function.

 

Option C. GLUT4: Incorrect. GLUT4 is an insulin-regulated glucose transporter found mainly in adipose tissues and muscle cells. It is not involved in the intestinal absorption of glucose and plays no role in ORS therapy.

 

Option D. Na-Ca transporter: Incorrect. The sodium-calcium exchanger (often referred to as NCX) is primarily involved in the transport of calcium and sodium ions across the cell membrane in many tissues, including cardiac muscle. It does not participate in glucose absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Human papilloma virus
Herpes simplex virus
Human immunodeficiency virus

questions.text: Which of the following is the causative organism of vulval warts? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Human papilloma virus

 

Explanation:

 

  • Benign vulval warts are caused by HPV-6 and 11 (low risk HPV types)

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Herpes simplex virus: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) causes genital herpes, characterized by painful vesicular lesions.

 

Option C. Human immunodeficiency virus: Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) causes AIDS, which leads to immunosuppression and various opportunistic infections.

 

Option D. Cytomegalovirus: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a member of the herpesvirus family and can cause infections in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not cause vulval warts.

 

Sexually Transmitted Infections

 

 

Educational Objective

 

Benign vulval warts (condyloma acuminata) are caused by HPV types 6 and 11.

 

Ref: Page no 146, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: 90% is associated with ANCA positivity
30% is associated with Hepatitis B

questions.text: Which of the following is true about polyarteritis nodosa? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 30% association with Hepatitis B

 

Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis predominantly affecting medium-sized arteries, often associated with Hepatitis B in about 30% of cases. The association with Hepatitis B is significant because the virus can trigger immune complex deposition, contributing to vascular inflammation and damage characteristic of PAN.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Necrotizing inflammation of large vessels: This is incorrect because PAN specifically affects medium-sized, not large vessels. Large vessel vasculitis includes conditions like Giant Cell Arteritis and Takayasu Arteritis.

 

Option B. Patient has hypogammaglobulinemia: This is incorrect; PAN is often associated with hypergammaglobulinemia due to chronic immune activation, not hypogammaglobulinemia.

 

Option C. 90% is associated with ANCA positivity: This statement is also incorrect. Polyarteritis nodosa is typically ANCA-negative; the presence of ANCA is more characteristic of other forms of vasculitis such as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA) and Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA).

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/Vasculitis/Chap 363

choices.text: A = pulmonary, B = aortic, C = tricuspid, D = mitral
A = aortic, B = pulmonary, C = tricuspid, D = mitral
A = tricuspid, B = aortic, C = pulmonary, D = mitral
A = aortic, B = tricuspid, C = pulmonary, D = mitral

questions.text: Correctly match the sites of cardiac valve auscultation from the given image: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A = aortic, B = pulmonary, C = tricuspid, D = mitral

 

The sites for auscultation of the cardiac valves are specific locations on the chest where the sounds of the heart valves can best be heard. These locations do not correspond directly to the anatomical position of the valves but are determined by the direction in which the sound travels through the body. Here is the correct matching:

 

  • A. Aortic valve: Auscultation is best performed in the second intercostal space at the right sternal border.
  • B. Pulmonary valve: This is auscultated in the second intercostal space at the left sternal border.
  • C. Tricuspid valve: The best location for auscultation is at the fourth or fifth intercostal space at the left sternal border.
  • D. Mitral valve: The mitral valve is auscultated at the apex of the heart, which is located in the fifth intercostal space at the midclavicular line.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The auscultation points for the heart valves are specific to each valve: Aortic (right second intercostal space), Pulmonary (left second intercostal space), Tricuspid (left fourth/fifth intercostal space), and Mitral (apex of the heart). Correct identification of these points is crucial for accurate cardiac examination.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant presents with a history of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), sensorineural hearing loss. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital rubella

 

The classic triad of congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) includes:

 

  • Patent ductus arteriosus (cardiac defect)
  • Sensorineural hearing loss (auditory defect)
  • Cataract/salt and pepper retinopathy (ocular defect)

 

The presence of PDA and sensorineural hearing loss strongly suggests congenital rubella infection. This occurs when a pregnant woman contracts rubella virus during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester when organogenesis is occurring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV): Though it can cause sensorineural hearing loss, it typically presents with microcephaly, periventricular calcifications, and hepatosplenomegaly rather than PDA.

 

Option C. Congenital toxoplasmosis: Classical features include hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis. PDA is not a typical finding.

 

Option D. Congenital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection: Usually presents with vesicular skin lesions, encephalitis, and keratoconjunctivitis. PDA and hearing loss are not typical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital rubella syndrome is characterized by the triad of 

 

  • Patent ductus arteriosus (cardiac defect)
  • Sensorineural hearing loss (auditory defect)
  • Cataract/salt and pepper retinopathy (ocular defect)

choices.text: Excessive venous pooling at the feet

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation presents to you with complaints of feeling light-headedness and dizziness when she lies on her back and feels relieved if she lies on her side or when walks. What is the most likely reason behind this? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IVC compression

 

Explanation:

 

The symptoms of light-headedness and dizziness that the pregnant woman experiences when lying on her back, which are relieved by lying on her side or walking, are indicative of inferior vena cava (IVC) compression. In the supine position during late pregnancy, the gravid uterus compresses the IVC, which can decrease venous return to the heart. This condition, known as supine hypotensive syndrome, leads to reduced cardiac output and can cause symptoms such as dizziness, light-headedness, and a decreased supply of oxygen and nutrients to vital organs.

 

  • Supine Hypotensive Syndrome: This occurs when the enlarged uterus compresses the IVC, reducing venous return to the heart, leading to symptoms like dizziness and light-headedness.
  • Relief by changing position: Symptoms are relieved when the woman lies on her side or walks because these positions alleviate the pressure on the IVC, improving venous return and cardiac output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased intracranial pressure: This would present with symptoms such as headache, vomiting, visual disturbances, and altered mental status, not positional dizziness relieved by lying on the side.

 

Option C. Heavy meals: While heavy meals can cause discomfort, they are unlikely to cause the specific positional symptoms described.

 

Option D. Excessive venous pooling at the feet: This might cause symptoms such as swelling and discomfort in the legs but not the specific positional dizziness described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inferior vena cava compression by the gravid uterus in late pregnancy can cause supine hypotensive syndrome, leading to light-headedness and dizziness when lying on the back, which is relieved by lying on the side or walking.

questions.text: A patient presents with a perforation in the tympanic membrane. During the evaluation, a Rinne test is performed. What is the expected outcome of the Rinne test in this case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Negative

 

Perforation of the tympanic membrane results in conductive hearing loss because the sound waves cannot be properly transmitted through the middle ear. In cases of conductive hearing loss, the Rinne test, which compares air conduction (AC) to bone conduction (BC), will be negative. This occurs because bone conduction is perceived as louder than air conduction, indicating a conductive defect. The negative Rinne test is characteristic of any lesion or abnormality affecting the external ear, tympanic membrane, or middle ear, as these structures are responsible for sound conduction.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Positive: A positive Rinne test indicates that air conduction is louder than bone conduction, which is normal or seen in sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive hearing loss like that caused by a tympanic membrane perforation.

 

Option C. Indeterminate: This is not a standard result for the Rinne test. The Rinne test is typically either positive or negative, and "indeterminate" does not correctly describe the results related to tympanic membrane perforation.

 

Option D. Equivocal: An equivocal Rinne test result suggests equal loudness of air and bone conduction, which is not typically associated with tympanic membrane perforation. This term is not commonly used in describing Rinne test outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A perforation in the tympanic membrane causes conductive hearing loss, which is characterized by a negative Rinne test, where bone conduction is heard louder than air conduction.

questions.text: The most common cancer found among the female population in India is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Breast cancer

 

In India, breast cancer is the most common cancer affecting the female population.

 

It ranks highest in terms of incidence, prevalence, and mortality among cancers in women.

 

Breast cancer has overtaken cervical cancer, which used to be the leading cause of cancer-related morbidity among Indian women. This shift reflects changes in lifestyle, reproductive patterns, and awareness.

 

Statistically, breast cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths among Indian women, and its incidence continues to rise, making it a significant public health concern. Additionally, breast cancer is also the most common cancer when considering the total population (both male and female) combined.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral and lip cancer: While oral and lip cancers are common in India, particularly due to tobacco use, they are more prevalent in males and do not surpass breast cancer in females in terms of incidence.

 

Option B. Cervical cancer: Cervical cancer was previously the most common cancer among women in India. However, breast cancer has now overtaken it in terms of both incidence and mortality.

 

Option D. Lung cancer: Lung cancer, while common, is more prevalent in males. It is not the most common cancer among females in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breast cancer is the most common cancer among the female population in India, leading in incidence, prevalence, and mortality rates. Followed by cervico-uterine cancer, ovarian cancer, lip and oral cavity cancer, and colorectal cancer, respectively.

questions.text: Methotrexate acts by inhibiting: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dihydrofolate reductase

 

Methotrexate is a chemotherapy agent and immune system suppressant. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase. This enzyme is crucial for the conversion of dihydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate, a form of folic acid that is required for the synthesis of thymidylate, purines, and the amino acid methionine.

 

By inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, methotrexate effectively depletes the cell’s supply of tetrahydrofolate, which in turn inhibits DNA, RNA, and protein synthesis. This inhibition is particularly effective against rapidly dividing cells, which is why methotrexate is used in the treatment of certain cancers and autoimmune diseases.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thymidylate synthetase: Thymidylate synthetase is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of thymidylate (dTMP) from deoxyuridylate (dUMP), which is necessary for DNA synthesis. This enzyme is inhibited by 5-Fluorouracil, not methotrexate.

 

Option B. DNA polymerase: DNA polymerase is an enzyme responsible for forming new copies of DNA, but methotrexate does not directly inhibit this enzyme. Inhibition of DNA polymerase would prevent DNA replication, but methotrexate acts upstream in the folate pathway.

 

Option C. RNA Polymerase: RNA polymerase is responsible for synthesizing RNA from a DNA template. Methotrexate does not inhibit RNA polymerase; instead, it inhibits the production of necessary components for DNA and RNA synthesis indirectly by depleting tetrahydrofolate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methotrexate acts by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase, thereby preventing the synthesis of DNA, RNA, and proteins by depleting tetrahydrofolate.

questions.text: Given the radiograph of a 13-year-old child who presented with fall on elbow. Which of the following bone is fractured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Humerus

 

  • The image shows fracture of the upper end of humerus.

 

PROXIMAL HUMERUS FRACTURE

 

  • Approximately 40% of metaphyseal proximal humerus fractures are non- or minimally displaced and more commonly require operative treatment as compared to epiphyseal fractures.
  • The peak of these fractures occurs between ages of 10-14 and again at 80-84 years with males more affected.
  • Proximal humerus fractures most often occur upon falling backwards onto an outstretched hand with an extended elbow and externally rotated shoulder or through direct traumatic impact to the shoulder. 
  • The Neer-Horowitz system is the most widely used classification system for proximal humerus fractures in children and is graded by severity of displacement.

 

 

  • On examination, there may be swelling, tenderness, visible deformity, and unwillingness to move the shoulder by holding the arm close to the body.
  • Associated injuries to the brachial plexus, clavicle, and scapula should not be missed.
  • Standard radiographs of the shoulder including AP, and axillary views are generally sufficient to characterize the fracture morphology.
  • The majority of proximal humerus fractures in children can be treated successfully with non-operative management due to the immense remodelling potential of the physis.
  • Neer-Horowitz grade I/II can be successfully treated non-operatively with immobilization in a hanging arm/shoulder spica cast and a sling for 3-4 weeks.
  • Operative treatment should be considered in Neer-Horowitz grade III and IV fractures and greater fracture angulation in older children.
  • Failure of closed reduction should be addressed with open reduction.
  • Fixation options include percutaneous pinning, intramedullary nails, cannulated screws, and plates.

 

 

  • Percutaneous pinning remains the most commonly used fixation strategy.
  • Prognosis in children are generally excellent with both non-operative and operative treatment. 
  • Complications are rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Clavicle. The clavicle is one of the most common fractured bones in children. These heal quickly and recover fully. Injuries are usually the result of a fall on an outstretched hand with the force transmitted up the arm. A direct blow to the outer end of the clavicle can be associated with distal third injuries and acromioclavicular joint disruption. The vast majority present with pain, swelling and deformity along the line of the clavicle, and a history of a fall onto an outstretched arm. Fractures of the medial third are usually the result of high impact blunt force to the anterior chest (such as in a motor vehicle accident), and can be associated with neurovascular, pulmonary and cardiac (rare) injuries. Careful airway protection and neurovascular assessment is required. Vascular assessment of the arm should also be performed as the subclavian artery runs close to the clavicle in the middle third. Standard AP with 15 degrees cephalic tilt x-ray of the clavicle will show the fracture in two planes and define displacement. The majority of clavicle fractures are easily managed with a sling and analgesia.

 

 

Option C. Scapula. Scapula fractures are uncommon in children. Scapular body fractures are usually the result of high-energy trauma such as motor vehicle collisions or falls. There is a high incidence of associated injuries including other shoulder girdle fractures, rib fractures, head injury, and lung injury, such as pneumothorax or pulmonary contusion. Glenoid fractures are often due to a direct blow to the lateral shoulder or a fall onto a flexed elbow with the humeral head being driven into the glenoid. The position of the arm dictates whether an anterior or posterior rim fracture occurs. Similarly, acromion fractures are usually due to a direct blow to the lateral shoulder. Coracoid fractures are usually an avulsive injury resulting from pull of the acromioclavicular ligaments or the conjoint tendon. Scapulothoracic dissociation is often due to a severe traction injury. The primary symptom is often pain about the shoulder or back and difficulty with motion. Numbness or weakness may be present with a concomitant brachial plexus injury. The majority of fractures are treated non-operatively. Treatment includes immobilization for 3-4 weeks followed by pendulum exercises and protected range of motion. 

 

Option D. Ribs. Rib fracture in children is caused by a high force injury. Ribs 1-3 are the hardest to break. Ribs 4-10 are typically the most vulnerable while ribs 11-12 are more mobile and therefore, more difficult to break. Since children tend to have more elastic ribs than adults, children are less likely to sustain rib fractures. Therefore, children with rib fractures is a sign of significant trauma and should warrant an investigation of possible child abuse. The physical exam may reveal chest wall bruising, along with bony tenderness to palpitation or crepitus. For simple, isolated rib fractures, conservative treatment is usually adequate which includes appropriate analgesia, rest, and ice. The use of an incentive spirometer should be encouraged to prevent pulmonary atelectasis and splinting. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image given in the question shows the fracture of upper end or proximal end of humerus.
